clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo's subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: This eternal city is home to the world's smallest country.
Ancient gladiators once fought in its iconic circular amphitheater.
fun_fact: About €3,000 worth of coins are tossed into the Trevi Fountain each day.
The Pantheon has the world's largest unreinforced concrete dome, built in 126 AD.
trivia: There are more than 2,000 fountains throughout the city.
The Romans invented concrete and used a secret recipe that made it stronger than modern concrete.

clues: Ancient pyramids stand guard over this modern metropolis.
The world's longest river flows through this capital city.
fun_fact: The city's Arabic name 'Al Qahira' means 'The Victorious'.
It's home to the only remaining wonder of the ancient world.
trivia: The Great Pyramid was the tallest man-made structure for over 3,800 years.
The city's Al-Azhar University is one of the oldest in the world, founded in 970 AD.

clues: Its harbor features a famous opera house with sail-like roofs.
Home to the world's largest natural harbor.
fun_fact: The Opera House's tiles were inspired by butterfly wings and imported from Sweden.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is nicknamed 'The Coathanger' due to its arch-based design.
trivia: The city's Bondi Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world.
Sydney Tower's height is exactly 1,001 feet as a tribute to '1001 Arabian Nights'.

clues: Home to the world's tallest building and artificial islands shaped like palm trees.
A modern oasis where you can ski indoors despite desert heat.
fun_fact: The police force uses luxury supercars including Bugattis and Lamborghinis.
25% of the world's construction cranes were once located in this city.
trivia: The Burj Khalifa is so tall that you can watch the sunset twice from it on the same day.
The city has the world's first 7-star hotel, the Burj Al Arab.

clues: A giant statue of Christ stands with open arms above this city.
Famous for its carnival and Copacabana beach.
fun_fact: The Christ the Redeemer statue is struck by lightning about 6 times a year.
The city's name means 'January River', though there's no actual river there.
trivia: It was once the capital of Portugal, the only European capital outside of Europe.
The Maracanã Stadium once held a crowd of 199,854, a world record for soccer.

clues: Red Square and colorful onion domes define this city's skyline.
Home to the world's most beautiful metro stations.
fun_fact: The Kremlin walls were originally white, not red.
Metro stations were designed as 'palaces for the people' with crystal chandeliers.
trivia: The city has more billionaires than any other city in the world.
Moscow's State Library is the largest in Europe with over 17 million books.

clues: Gaudí's unfinished masterpiece cathedral still draws millions of visitors.
Famous for its unique modernist architecture and Las Ramblas.
fun_fact: The Sagrada Familia has been under construction for over 140 years.
The city has 9 UNESCO World Heritage sites, most of them designed by Gaudí.
trivia: The city's grid pattern was designed to allow wind from the mountains to flow through.
Barcelona's beach is artificial, created for the 1992 Olympics.

clues: This city-state features a hotel with an infinity pool on top of three towers.
Known for its spotless streets and ban on chewing gum.
fun_fact: It's one of only three city-states in the world.
The Singapore Botanic Gardens is the only tropical garden recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage site.
trivia: The national anthem is printed in microtext on the back of the $1000 note.
It's home to the world's first night safari and largest glass greenhouse.

clues: More bicycles than people in this canal-lined city.
Famous for its narrow houses and floating flower market.
fun_fact: All houses are slightly tilted forward to help move furniture up using pulleys.
There are over 1,200 bridges in Amsterdam, three times more than Venice.
trivia: The narrowest house in Amsterdam is just 2.02 meters wide.
Many houses are built on wooden poles due to the swampy ground.

clues: The world's largest ancient castle complex overlooks this city.
Famous for its medieval astronomical clock still ticking since 1410.
fun_fact: The Dancing House was inspired by Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.
Prague Castle covers an area larger than seven football fields.
trivia: The city has over 300 spires, earning it the nickname 'City of a Hundred Spires'.
Charles Bridge is built with eggs mixed into the mortar for strength.

clues: Colorful houses line the streets of La Boca neighborhood.
The birthplace of tango and home to the world's most beautiful bookstore.
fun_fact: The city has more bookstores per capita than any other city in the world.
It's home to the widest avenue in the world, 9 de Julio Avenue.
trivia: The city's subway is the oldest in South America, opened in 1913.
El Ateneo Grand Splendid bookstore was originally a theater.

clues: Classical music, coffee houses, and imperial palaces define this city.
Home to the Spanish Riding School and its famous Lipizzan horses.
fun_fact: The snow globe was invented in Vienna in 1900.
The city's central cemetery has more residents than the living city.
trivia: Vienna has been ranked the world's most liveable city multiple times.
The croissant was invented here to celebrate defeating the Ottoman Empire.

clues: Famous for its steep hills and iconic red bridge.
Historic cable cars still climb the city's 43 hills.
fun_fact: The Golden Gate Bridge's color is officially 'International Orange'.
The city's famous sourdough bread is unique due to local bacteria.
trivia: The city was built on top of dozens of abandoned ships from the Gold Rush.
Alcatraz means 'pelican' in Spanish due to the birds on the island.

clues: Built on 14 islands connected by 57 bridges.
Home to the Nobel Prize ceremonies and museum.
fun_fact: The city's subway system is known as the world's longest art gallery.
Stockholm's Old Town, Gamla Stan, dates back to the 13th century.
trivia: The city hall is made of 8 million bricks and features a golden hall.
The ABBA museum has a piano connected to Benny's home piano.

clues: Ancient palaces stand alongside modern K-pop culture.
Famous for its street food and 24-hour shopping districts.
fun_fact: The city's Lotte World Tower has the world's fastest elevator.
Seoul's Gangnam district was farmland just 40 years ago.
trivia: The city has free WiFi access in all public spaces and subway stations.
Seoul's Myeongdong district can see up to 2 million visitors per day.

clues: Built on an ancient lake bed with Aztec ruins in its center.
Home to the world's smallest volcano and largest bullring.
fun_fact: The city is sinking at a rate of about 20 cm per year.
It was once the largest city in the world during the Aztec period.
trivia: The city has more museums than any other city in the world.
The main cathedral is built with stones from destroyed Aztec temples.

clues: Home to the world's largest film industry, Bollywood.
Features the iconic Gateway of India and Victorian architecture.
fun_fact: The city's dabbawalas deliver 200,000 lunch boxes daily with 99.99% accuracy.
Dharavi is one of Asia's largest slums but also a $1 billion business hub.
trivia: The city was originally seven separate islands.
Mumbai's Victorian Gothic buildings are a UNESCO World Heritage site.

clues: A once-divided city where part of the wall still stands as art.
Known for its vibrant street art and techno music scene.
fun_fact: The city has more bridges than Venice.
Berlin's TV Tower is visible from every district of the city.
trivia: There are more doner kebab shops in Berlin than in Istanbul.
The city's East Side Gallery is the longest open-air gallery in the world.

clues: Famous for floating markets and golden temples.
Its full ceremonial name is the longest city name in the world.
fun_fact: The full name of Bangkok is 169 characters long.
The city is sinking 2-3 centimeters every year.
trivia: It's known as the 'City of Angels' in Thai.
The city's Wat Phra Kaew temple has never housed monks.

clues: Sacred to three major religions with ancient walls surrounding the old city.
Home to some of the world's oldest religious sites.
fun_fact: The city has been captured and recaptured 44 times throughout history.
The Old City walls were built by Suleiman the Magnificent in the 16th century.
trivia: The city has over 2,000 archaeological sites.
Jerusalem Syndrome is a psychological phenomenon specific to the city.

clues: Home to the Little Mermaid statue and colorful Nyhavn harbor.
Known for its cycling culture and modern design.
fun_fact: The city has more bikes than people and 350km of bike lanes.
Tivoli Gardens inspired Walt Disney to create Disneyland.
trivia: The city aims to become the first carbon-neutral capital by 2025.
The average Copenhagener cycles 3km per day.

clues: Former imperial capital with over 1,600 Buddhist temples.
Famous for its traditional gardens and geisha district.
fun_fact: The city was removed from the atomic bomb target list due to its cultural significance.
Nintendo was founded here in 1889 as a playing card company.
trivia: The city has 17 UNESCO World Heritage sites.
Kyoto's street grid pattern was modeled after ancient Chinese cities.

clues: A castle on a volcanic rock overlooks this city of festivals.
Known for its medieval Old Town and Georgian New Town.
fun_fact: The city was built on seven hills, like Rome.
J.K. Rowling wrote Harry Potter in local cafes here.
trivia: The Royal Mile is actually 1.12 miles long.
It was the first city in the world to have its own fire brigade.

clues: Known for its maze-like medina and vibrant souks.
Famous for its red walls and Jardin Majorelle.
fun_fact: All buildings must be painted in salmon-pink or ochre.
The medina has 19 gates and over 200 neighborhoods.
trivia: Jemaa el-Fnaa square has been a marketplace since the 11th century.
The city's name means 'Land of God' in Berber.

clues: Built on 42 islands with hundreds of bridges.
Home to the Hermitage Museum and famous White Nights.
fun_fact: The city's bridges open at night to let ships pass through.
The Hermitage has so many exhibits it would take 11 years to see them all.
trivia: The city changed its name three times in the 20th century.
It has the deepest metro system in the world.

clues: Table Mountain creates a dramatic backdrop for this coastal city.
Home to Robben Island where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned.
fun_fact: The Cape Floral Kingdom is the smallest yet richest in the world.
Table Mountain is one of the oldest mountains on Earth.
trivia: It was the first city outside Europe to get Blue Flag Beach status.
The Castle of Good Hope is the oldest colonial building in South Africa.

clues: Famous for its vintage cars and colorful colonial architecture.
The Malecón seawall is known as 'Cuba's living room'.
fun_fact: The city has the largest collection of Spanish colonial architecture in the Americas.
Ernest Hemingway wrote 'The Old Man and the Sea' while living here.
trivia: The National Capitol building is slightly taller than the US Capitol.
The city's harbor was once closed by a huge iron chain each night.

clues: Built on seven hills with vintage yellow trams climbing steep streets.
Famous for its blue and white tiles and fado music.
fun_fact: The city's São Jorge Castle survived an earthquake that destroyed 85% of the city.
Vasco da Gama's tomb is held in Jerónimos Monastery.
trivia: It's the oldest city in Western Europe, predating London and Paris.
The city's famous pastéis de nata recipe is still a secret.

clues: The Acropolis watches over this ancient city of democracy.
Birthplace of the Olympic Games and classical philosophy.
fun_fact: The city has been continuously inhabited for over 7,000 years.
Ancient Athenians voted to exile citizens they found annoying.
trivia: The Parthenon was built without straight lines to appear perfect.
The modern marathon distance was set from Athens to Marathon.

clues: Surrounded by mountains and ocean, known for its stunning natural beauty.
Home to Stanley Park, one of the largest urban parks in North America.
fun_fact: The city has the longest uninterrupted waterfront path in the world.
It's been ranked as one of the top 3 most liveable cities for over a decade.
trivia: Greenpeace was founded in this city in 1971.
The steam clock in Gastown is actually powered by electricity.

clues: The Bund waterfront showcases both colonial and futuristic architecture.
Home to the world's second-tallest building and fastest train.
fun_fact: The word 'Shanghai' literally means 'Upon the Sea'.
The city has more miles of subway than London and New York combined.
trivia: It has the world's first commercial maglev train.
The city was once known as the 'Paris of the East'.

clues: Birthplace of the Renaissance and home to Michelangelo's David.
The Duomo cathedral dome was an architectural marvel of its time.
fun_fact: The Stendhal syndrome was first identified here after tourists were overwhelmed by art.
The city's Uffizi Gallery was the first modern museum in Europe.
trivia: The piano was invented here by Bartolomeo Cristofori.
The city's Ponte Vecchio is the only bridge that survived WWII.

clues: Famous for the Petronas Twin Towers and their sky bridge.
Known for its mix of colonial, Asian, and modern architecture.
fun_fact: The Petronas Towers were the world's tallest buildings from 1998-2004.
The city's name means 'muddy confluence' in Malay.
trivia: It has the world's largest free-flight walk-in aviary.
The city started as a tin mining settlement in the 1850s.

clues: Home to Trinity College and the Book of Kells.
The Guinness Storehouse is its most visited tourist attraction.
fun_fact: The St. James's Gate Brewery had a 9,000-year lease signed in 1759.
Phoenix Park is the largest urban park in Europe.
trivia: The city has produced four Nobel Prize winners for literature.
The Ha'penny Bridge got its name from the toll once charged to cross it.

clues: Former capital of the Inca Empire with perfect stone architecture.
Gateway to Machu Picchu and the Sacred Valley.
fun_fact: The city was built in the shape of a puma, a sacred Inca animal.
Inca walls were built without mortar and have survived earthquakes.
trivia: The city's name means 'navel' in Quechua.
Spanish colonists built their churches on top of Inca temples.

clues: Known for its European charm and underground city.
Home to the world's largest jazz festival.
fun_fact: The underground city connects 32km of tunnels beneath downtown.
Mount Royal has a law restricting buildings from being taller than it.
trivia: It's the second-largest French-speaking city after Paris.
The city has more restaurants per capita than New York City.

clues: City of canals and palaces built by Peter the Great.
Home to the world's largest art museum, the Hermitage.
fun_fact: The city was built on swampland and 101 islands.
During summer, the sun never fully sets for about 80 days.
trivia: The Hermitage has cats on staff to control rodents.
It was Russia's capital city for more than 200 years.

clues: Home to the world's oldest university and largest car-free urban area.
Famous for its ancient leather tanneries and medieval medina.
fun_fact: The medina contains over 9,000 narrow streets and alleys.
The blue gates of the city were originally green but oxidized over time.
trivia: The Fez hat was named after the city where it originated.
The city's tanneries have operated continuously since the 9th century.

clues: Medieval market square is the largest in Europe.
Home to the legendary Wawel Dragon and castle.
fun_fact: The city's trumpet signal gets cut off mid-note to commemorate a fallen trumpeter.
It was one of the few Polish cities not destroyed in WWII.
trivia: The city has the world's oldest shopping mall, the Cloth Hall.
Leonardo da Vinci's Lady with an Ermine is housed here.

clues: Known for its Old Quarter and Temple of Literature.
Famous for its street food culture and water puppet theater.
fun_fact: The city has been continuously inhabited for over 1,000 years.
Hoan Kiem Lake contains a rare species of giant softshell turtle.
trivia: The city has over 100 lakes within its boundaries.
The Long Bien Bridge was designed by Gustave Eiffel.

clues: Only walled city north of Mexico in North America.
Famous for its winter carnival and Château Frontenac.
fun_fact: The Château Frontenac is the most photographed hotel in the world.
The city's old town is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
trivia: It's the oldest French-speaking city in North America.
The city has a toboggan run that's been operating since 1884.

clues: Known as the Pink City for its colored buildings.
Home to the Hawa Mahal and Amber Fort.
fun_fact: The city was painted pink to welcome Prince Albert in 1876.
The Jantar Mantar observatory can tell time to within 2 seconds.
trivia: It was India's first planned city.
The city's architecture follows ancient Hindu architectural principles.

clues: Famous for port wine and the Dom Luis I Bridge.
Home to one of the world's most beautiful bookstores.
fun_fact: The Lello Bookstore inspired J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
The Francesinha sandwich was invented here.
trivia: The city gave its name to both Portugal and port wine.
It has six bridges, all built in different centuries.

clues: Colorful colonial city surrounded by historic walls.
Known for its Caribbean beaches and fortress.
fun_fact: The city's walls took 200 years to complete.
It was the first Spanish colony to gain independence.
trivia: Gabriel García Márquez based many stories here.
The fortress survived numerous pirate attacks.

clues: Ancient city surrounded by a moat and wall.
Known for its hundreds of temples and night bazaar.
fun_fact: The city has over 300 temples within its metropolitan area.
It was the capital of the Lanna Kingdom for 500 years.
trivia: The city hosts the world's largest Songkran festival.
Its oldest temple dates back to 1296.

clues: World's southernmost capital city.
Known for its strong winds and film industry.
fun_fact: It has more cafes per capita than New York City.
The city's cable car has been running since 1902.
trivia: The city is built on active geological fault lines.
It's nicknamed 'Wellywood' due to its film industry.

clues: Pearl of the Adriatic with massive stone walls.
Famous filming location for Game of Thrones.
fun_fact: The city walls have never been breached by a hostile army.
The main street is limestone and becomes slippery from wear.
trivia: It was an independent republic for centuries.
The pharmacy in the Franciscan Monastery has operated since 1317.

clues: UNESCO town known for morning alms giving to monks.
Situated at the confluence of the Mekong and Nam Khan rivers.
fun_fact: The entire town is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It was the royal capital until 1975.
trivia: The name means 'Royal Buddha Image'.
It has 33 golden temples in its historic center.

clues: First capital of Brazil with colorful colonial architecture.
Known for its African heritage and carnival celebrations.
fun_fact: The Lacerda Elevator was the world's first public elevator.
The historic center has over 800 preserved colonial buildings.
trivia: It was the first slave port in the Americas.
The city's carnival is the largest street party in the world.

clues: Best-preserved medieval city in Northern Europe.
Known for its digital innovation and startup culture.
fun_fact: The city's Old Town hasn't changed much since the 15th century.
It was the first country to hold elections over the internet.
trivia: Skype was developed here.
The city's Christmas market tradition dates back to 1441.

clues: Known for its colorful houses and funicular elevators.
Pablo Neruda's house overlooks this port city.
fun_fact: The city has 42 hills connected by historic funiculars.
It's known as 'The Jewel of the Pacific'.
trivia: The city inspired many of Pablo Neruda's poems.
It was Latin America's first stock exchange.

clues: City of Lakes with floating marble palaces.
Known as the Venice of the East.
fun_fact: The Lake Palace appears to float on Lake Pichola.
It was featured in the James Bond film 'Octopussy'.
trivia: The city never came under Mughal rule.
It has one of the largest solar power plants in Asia.

clues: Romantic city with Germany's oldest university.
Famous for its partially ruined castle on the hill.
fun_fact: The castle contains the world's largest wine barrel.
Mark Twain wrote extensively about the city in his travelogues.
trivia: The city was largely spared from WWII bombing.
Its university library is the oldest in Germany.

clues: Colonial city surrounded by volcanoes.
Known for its preserved Spanish Baroque architecture.
fun_fact: The city was the capital of Central America for over 200 years.
It has the oldest Holy Week celebrations in the Americas.
trivia: The entire city is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It has over 30 monastic complexes in ruins.

clues: Ancient trading port known for its lanterns.
Famous for its mix of architectural styles.
fun_fact: The city's name means 'peaceful meeting place'.
It was a major ceramics trading port in the 16th century.
trivia: Cars and motorbikes are banned from the Old Town.
The city holds a full moon lantern festival every month.

clues: Gateway to the fjords with colorful wooden houses.
Home to the UNESCO-listed Bryggen wharf.
fun_fact: It rains 240 days a year on average.
The city was the largest in Scandinavia in the Middle Ages.
trivia: Edvard Grieg's home is now a museum.
It was a major Hanseatic League trading post.

clues: Colorful colonial city built over silver mines.
Famous for its underground tunnel system.
fun_fact: The city's tunnels were originally built for flood control.
It produces 30% of Mexico's silver.
trivia: The city hosts the largest arts festival in Latin America.
It has a museum dedicated to Don Quixote.

clues: Known as the Jerusalem of Europe for its religious diversity.
Site where World War I began.
fun_fact: The city has the oldest continuously running film festival in Southeast Europe.
Its National Library was rebuilt from millions of ashes.
trivia: It hosted the 1984 Winter Olympics.
The city has the largest market square in Europe.

clues: Home to the golden Shwedagon Pagoda.
Known for its colonial architecture and circular train.
fun_fact: The Shwedagon Pagoda contains more gold than the Bank of England's vaults.
The city has the highest number of colonial buildings in Southeast Asia.
trivia: It was once known as Rangoon.
The pagoda is believed to be 2,600 years old.

clues: World's northernmost capital city.
Known for its colorful houses and geothermal pools.
fun_fact: The city is heated entirely by geothermal energy.
You can see the Northern Lights from downtown in winter.
trivia: The city has no mosquitoes.
It's one of the cleanest cities in the world due to lack of heavy industry.

clues: Ancient city carved into rose-colored rock.
Famous for its narrow canyon entrance and Treasury building.
fun_fact: Only 15% of the ancient city has been uncovered.
The city's water conduit system was far ahead of its time.
trivia: It was unknown to the Western world until 1812.
Featured in Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade.

clues: Famous for port wine cellars and iron bridge.
Known for its stunning blue-tiled churches.
fun_fact: The Harry Potter series was partially written here.
The Dom Luis I Bridge was designed by a student of Gustave Eiffel.
trivia: Port wine must be stored in Porto to be called Port.
The Majestic Café is one of the world's most beautiful cafes.

clues: One of the world's oldest continuously inhabited cities.
Sacred city on the banks of the Ganges River.
fun_fact: Mark Twain said it's older than history, tradition, and legend.
The city has over 87 ghats (riverside steps).
trivia: It's considered the spiritual capital of India.
The city is sacred to both Hindus and Buddhists.

clues: Known for its colonial architecture and art scene.
Famous for its neo-Gothic church with pink spires.
fun_fact: The city hasn't had traffic lights for over 50 years.
It was named after a hero of Mexican independence.
trivia: It's a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The city was once a major silver mining hub.

clues: Dragon is the symbol of this green capital.
Known for its Triple Bridge and castle on the hill.
fun_fact: The city's name means 'beloved' in Slovene.
It was the first European capital to aim for zero waste.
trivia: Most of its old town is pedestrian-only.
The castle has stood for over 900 years.

clues: Ancient Silk Road city with over 140 monuments.
Known for its trading domes and ancient minarets.
fun_fact: The city's architecture hasn't changed much in 2,000 years.
It was once a major center of Islamic learning.
trivia: Marco Polo visited the city in the 13th century.
It has Central Asia's oldest mosque.

clues: Known as Little Venice for its canals.
Famous for its colorful half-timbered houses.
fun_fact: The city inspired the setting of 'Beauty and the Beast'.
It's one of the driest cities in France due to the Vosges Mountains.
trivia: The creator of the Statue of Liberty was born here.
The city has been French and German five times each.

clues: Known for its sulfur baths and diverse architecture.
Famous for its traditional balconied houses.
fun_fact: The city's name means 'warm' due to its hot springs.
It's built on an ancient Silk Road route.
trivia: Wine-making began here over 8,000 years ago.
The city has been destroyed and rebuilt 29 times.

clues: Medieval city with more historic buildings than Bruges.
Known for its three towers and light festival.
fun_fact: The city was larger than London in the Middle Ages.
It has the world's largest flower show under glass.
trivia: The Ghent Altarpiece is the most stolen artwork ever.
It was the birthplace of Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor.

clues: Famous for its covered wooden bridge and lake.
Known for its well-preserved medieval architecture.
fun_fact: The Kapellbrücke is Europe's oldest covered bridge.
The city's famous Lion Monument moved Mark Twain to tears.
trivia: Wagner composed many works while living here.
The city's name comes from the Latin word for 'lantern'.

clues: Former imperial capital with a massive citadel.
Known for its royal tombs and pagodas.
fun_fact: The imperial city was modeled after Beijing's Forbidden City.
Royal meals had to include 50 different dishes.
trivia: It was the capital of Vietnam from 1802-1945.
The city's perfume river was named for flowers falling in autumn.

clues: Europe's oldest continuously inhabited city.
Built on seven hills like Rome.
fun_fact: The city has been inhabited for over 8,000 years.
It has the best-preserved Roman theater in the Balkans.
trivia: It was once called Philippopolis after Philip II of Macedon.
The city has been part of five different empires.

clues: The White City, built from volcanic stone.
Known for its colonial architecture and volcanoes.
fun_fact: The city's white buildings are made from sillar, volcanic rock.
It has over 300 days of sunshine per year.
trivia: The Santa Catalina Monastery is a city within a city.
It was founded in 1540 by Spanish conquistadors.

clues: Known for its traditional hanok village.
Birthplace of bibimbap and traditional paper.
fun_fact: The city has over 800 traditional Korean houses.
It was designated as a UNESCO City of Gastronomy.
trivia: The city was the birthplace of the Joseon Dynasty.
It hosts the largest food festival in Korea.

clues: Famous for its iconic Old Bridge over the Neretva River.
Known for its bridge diving tradition.
fun_fact: The bridge was built using egg whites in the mortar.
Local divers have jumped from the bridge for over 450 years.
trivia: The bridge stood for 427 years before being destroyed in war.
The city's name means 'bridge-keeper'.

clues: City of Popes with massive medieval ramparts.
Known for its bridge immortalized in a famous song.
fun_fact: The Papal Palace is the largest Gothic building in Europe.
Seven popes resided here instead of Rome.
trivia: The city walls are among the best preserved in France.
Its famous bridge only spans halfway across the river.

clues: Ancient walled city with complete Ming Dynasty architecture.
China's first banking center.
fun_fact: The city's layout represents a turtle, an ancient symbol of longevity.
It had China's first draft banks and checks.
trivia: The city walls have 72 watchtowers.
It's nicknamed the 'Chinese Wall Street of the past'.

clues: Fairytale town with a castle and Baroque theater.
Built within a meandering river bend.
fun_fact: The castle's theater is one of only two Baroque theaters remaining in the world.
Bears have lived in the castle moat since the 16th century.
trivia: The town's name means 'Czech curved meadow'.
It has one of the best-preserved Baroque theaters in Europe.

clues: Fortified coastal town known for its blue boats.
Famous for its annual Gnaoua World Music Festival.
fun_fact: Jimi Hendrix was inspired to write 'Castles Made of Sand' here.
Game of Thrones filmed scenes in its port.
trivia: The city was designed by a French architect for a Moroccan sultan.
It's known as the 'Wind City of Africa'.

clues: Romantic town with colorful palaces and castles.
Known for its mystical fog and lush gardens.
fun_fact: The Pena Palace was built to be visible from any point in the park.
Lord Byron called it a 'glorious Eden'.
trivia: It was the first center of European Romantic architecture.
The town has secret tunnels connecting its palaces.

clues: Japan's first permanent capital with friendly deer.
Home to the world's largest wooden building.
fun_fact: The deer are considered messengers of the gods.
The Great Buddha statue contains 437 kg of gold.
trivia: It has eight UNESCO World Heritage sites.
The city's deer have learned to bow for treats.

clues: Silent City with medieval walls and noble houses.
Former capital of Malta.
fun_fact: Cars are restricted, making it eerily quiet.
It served as King's Landing in Game of Thrones.
trivia: The city's history spans over 4,000 years.
Its streets were designed to amplify wind for cooling.

clues: Medieval city surrounded by the Carpathian Mountains.
Known for its Black Church and Council Square.
fun_fact: It has the narrowest street in Eastern Europe.
The Black Church is the largest Gothic church east of Vienna.
trivia: The city has its own Hollywood-style sign.
Dracula's castle is nearby in Bran.

clues: Colonial city surrounded by volcanoes.
Known for its preserved Spanish Baroque architecture.
fun_fact: The city was deliberately built to withstand earthquakes.
It has the oldest Holy Week celebrations in the Americas.
trivia: The entire city is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It was the capital of Central America for over 200 years.

clues: Roman temple and medieval walls in the heart of Alentejo.
Known for its Chapel of Bones.
fun_fact: The Chapel of Bones is made from over 5,000 human skeletons.
The city's Roman temple survived because it was walled up.
trivia: It was an important Jewish center in medieval times.
The university was founded in 1559.

clues: Coastal town in Europe's southernmost fjord.
Known for its medieval fortifications and cats.
fun_fact: The city walls are illuminated at night creating a 'snake of light'.
It has a museum dedicated to cats.
trivia: The walls were built over 1,000 years.
The city survived numerous earthquakes.

clues: Famous for its Roman aqueduct and fairytale castle.
Known for its roast suckling pig.
fun_fact: The aqueduct was built without mortar or cement.
The Alcázar inspired Walt Disney's Cinderella Castle.
trivia: The aqueduct has 166 arches.
Isabella I was proclaimed Queen of Castile here.

clues: Ancient royal capital with golden temples.
Known for its morning alms-giving ceremony.
fun_fact: The entire town is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It was the royal capital until 1975.
trivia: The name means 'Royal Buddha Image'.
It has 33 temples in its historic center.

clues: Golden sandstone fort city in the Thar Desert.
Known as the Golden City for its yellow sandstone architecture.
fun_fact: It's one of the world's few living forts with a quarter of the city's population residing inside.
The fort has survived multiple earthquakes due to its flexible foundation.
trivia: The city was a strategic point on ancient trade routes.
Many buildings use interlocking stones without mortar.

clues: Best-preserved medieval town on the Romantic Road.
Famous for its Christmas markets and intact city walls.
fun_fact: The town was saved in WWII when a US general refused to bomb it.
The Night Watchman's Tour has been running since medieval times.
trivia: It inspired the village in Pinocchio.
The town has looked the same since the 1600s.

clues: Ancient city complex with massive temple ruins.
Home to Angkor Wat, the world's largest religious monument.
fun_fact: The city was the largest pre-industrial urban center in the world.
The temples are aligned to mark solstices and equinoxes.
trivia: It took 30 years to build Angkor Wat.
The complex covers an area larger than Paris.

clues: Known as the Florence of the South.
Famous for its elaborate Baroque architecture.
fun_fact: The local limestone is so soft it can be carved with a knife.
The city has a Roman amphitheater in its main square.
trivia: It's called the 'City of Churches' with over 40 churches.
The local stone turns golden in sunlight.

clues: World's largest car-free urban area.
Known for its ancient leather tanneries.
fun_fact: The medina has over 9,000 streets and alleys.
The University of Al Quaraouiyine is the oldest in the world.
trivia: The Fez hat originated here.
The tanneries use the same techniques from the 11th century.

clues: Known for having the largest medieval old town in Eastern Europe.
Famous for its baroque churches and artist republic.
fun_fact: It has a self-declared independent republic within the city (Užupis).
The city center is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
trivia: It's known as the 'Jerusalem of the North'.
The city has a statue of Frank Zappa despite him never visiting.

clues: Colonial mining town built on steep hills.
Known for its Baroque churches and gold mines.
fun_fact: The city's name means 'Black Gold' in Portuguese.
It was Brazil's first UNESCO World Heritage site.
trivia: The city produced 80% of the world's gold in the 18th century.
Streets are paved with iron-rich stones that sparkle.

clues: Medieval city known as the Venice of the North.
Famous for its canals and chocolate shops.
fun_fact: The city's belfry houses a treasure vault.
It has more castles per square mile than anywhere else in the world.
trivia: The city center hasn't changed much since 1600.
It was one of the world's first tourist destinations.

clues: Ancient capital of the Inca Empire.
Known for its perfect stone architecture.
fun_fact: The city was built in the shape of a puma.
Stones in Inca walls are so precisely cut you can't insert a knife between them.
trivia: It's the oldest continuously inhabited city in the Americas.
The name means 'navel' in Quechua.

clues: Pearl of the Adriatic with massive stone walls.
Famous filming location for Game of Thrones.
fun_fact: The city walls have never been breached.
The main street is polished smooth by millions of footsteps.
trivia: It was an independent republic for centuries.
The pharmacy has operated since 1317.

clues: Known as the Venice of the East for its gardens and canals.
Famous for its classical Chinese gardens.
fun_fact: The gardens are designed to recreate natural landscapes in miniature.
Marco Polo called it 'Venice of the East'.
trivia: It has nine gardens listed as UNESCO World Heritage sites.
The city was founded in 514 BC.

clues: Medieval city known for its horse race, the Palio.
Famous for its fan-shaped central square.
fun_fact: The city is divided into 17 contrade (districts) with animal symbols.
The Palio tradition dates back to 1644.
trivia: The main square is shaped like an amphitheater.
The Black Death halted construction of what would have been the largest cathedral in the world.

clues: The Blue Pearl of Morocco with blue-painted buildings.
Known for its striking blue-washed old town.
fun_fact: The blue color was introduced by Jewish refugees in 1930.
The blue is said to repel mosquitoes.
trivia: The name means 'look at the horns' in Berber.
It was founded in 1471 as a fortress.

clues: Romantic city with Germany's oldest university.
Known for its partially ruined castle.
fun_fact: The castle contains the world's largest wine barrel.
Mark Twain wrote extensively about the city.
trivia: The university was founded in 1386.
The city was largely spared from WWII bombing.

clues: Ancient trading port known for its lanterns.
Famous for its mix of architectural styles.
fun_fact: The city's name means 'peaceful meeting place'.
It was a major ceramics trading port in the 16th century.
trivia: Cars are banned from the Old Town.
The city holds a full moon lantern festival monthly.

clues: Colorful colonial city built over silver mines.
Known for its underground tunnel system.
fun_fact: The tunnels were originally river diversions.
It produces 30% of Mexico's silver.
trivia: It hosts Latin America's largest arts festival.
The city has a museum of mummies.

clues: Best-preserved medieval city in Northern Europe.
Known for its digital innovation and startup culture.
fun_fact: The Old Town hasn't changed much since the 15th century.
First country to hold elections over the internet.
trivia: Skype was developed here.
The Christmas market tradition dates to 1441.

clues: Colorful colonial city with massive walls.
Known for its Caribbean beaches and fortress.
fun_fact: The walls took 200 years to complete.
It was the first Spanish colony to gain independence.
trivia: Gabriel García Márquez based many stories here.
Pirates never successfully invaded the city.

clues: Birthplace of Mozart and setting of The Sound of Music.
Known for its baroque architecture and music festivals.
fun_fact: The fortress has never been captured by foreign troops.
The city's name means 'Salt Castle'.
trivia: Mozart's birth house is now a museum.
The first Mozartkugel chocolate was made here.

clues: The Pink City with elaborate palaces.
Known for its geometric city planning.
fun_fact: The city was painted pink to welcome Prince Albert in 1876.
The Hawa Mahal has 953 windows.
trivia: It was India's first planned city.
The city follows ancient Hindu architectural principles.

clues: Medieval town with a castle and Baroque theater.
Built within a meandering river bend.
fun_fact: Bears have lived in the castle moat since the 16th century.
The castle theater is one of only two Baroque theaters remaining in the world.
trivia: The name means 'Czech curved meadow'.
The town hasn't changed much since the 18th century.

clues: Colonial city surrounded by volcanoes.
Known for its preserved Spanish Baroque architecture.
fun_fact: The city was the capital of Central America for 200 years.
It has the oldest Holy Week celebrations in the Americas.
trivia: The entire city is a UNESCO World Heritage site.
It has over 30 monastic complexes in ruins.

clues: Romantic town with colorful palaces.
Known for its mystical fog and gardens.
fun_fact: The Pena Palace was built to be visible from anywhere in the park.
Lord Byron called it 'glorious Eden'.
trivia: It was Europe's first center of Romantic architecture.
The town has secret tunnels connecting its palaces.

clues: Ancient Silk Road city with over 140 monuments.
Known for its trading domes and minarets.
fun_fact: The city's architecture hasn't changed much in 2,000 years.
It was once a major center of Islamic learning.
trivia: Marco Polo visited in the 13th century.
It has Central Asia's oldest mosque.

clues: Silent City with medieval walls.
Former capital of Malta.
fun_fact: Cars are restricted, making it eerily quiet.
It served as King's Landing in Game of Thrones.
trivia: The city's history spans over 4,000 years.
Streets were designed to amplify wind for cooling.

clues: Europe's oldest continuously inhabited city.
Built on seven hills like Rome.
fun_fact: The city has been inhabited for over 8,000 years.
It has the best-preserved Roman theater in the Balkans.
trivia: It was called Philippopolis after Philip II of Macedon.
The city has been part of five different empires.

clues: Roman temple and medieval walls in Alentejo.
Known for its Chapel of Bones.
fun_fact: The Chapel is made from over 5,000 human skeletons.
The Roman temple survived by being walled up.
trivia: It was an important Jewish center in medieval times.
The university was founded in 1559.

clues: Ancient city of cave dwellings called Sassi.
One of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world.
fun_fact: The caves have been inhabited for over 9,000 years.
It was used as a filming location for 'The Passion of the Christ'.
trivia: People lived in the caves until the 1950s.
It was named European Capital of Culture 2019.

clues: Ancient ruins of Vijayanagara Empire among boulder hills.
Known for its temple architecture and stone chariot.
fun_fact: The city was once the world's second-largest medieval-era city.
The boulders are over 3.5 billion years old.
trivia: The city's bazaar once traded in diamonds and precious stones.
The musical pillars in Vittala Temple produce musical notes when struck.

clues: Medieval walled town given as a wedding gift to queens.
Known for its whitewashed houses with blue trim.
fun_fact: Portuguese queens owned the town for 600 years.
The local cherry liqueur is served in chocolate cups.
trivia: The entire town was a wedding gift in 1282.
The castle is now a luxury hotel.

clues: Ancient Buddhist learning center and archaeological site.
Important stop on the Silk Road.
fun_fact: Alexander the Great built one of the city's settlements.
It was one of the world's first universities.
trivia: The city has remains from three distinct ancient cities.
It was a major center of Buddhist learning for 1,000 years.

clues: Colonial town with cobblestone streets and pastel houses.
Known for its sugar trade history.
fun_fact: The city's wealth came from over 50 nearby sugar mills.
The bell tower offers views of both mountains and sea.
trivia: It's called the 'Museum City of Cuba'.
The city hasn't changed much since the 19th century.

clues: City of stone with Ottoman-era tower houses.
Known as the 'City of a Thousand Steps'.
fun_fact: The city's castle contains a captured US spy plane.
Every house is covered with grey slate from local quarries.
trivia: It's the birthplace of former dictator Enver Hoxha.
The old bazaar has been active since the 17th century.

clues: Fourth holiest city in Islam with grand mosque.
Known for its carpet making and religious architecture.
fun_fact: The city's wells are said to connect to Mecca's Zamzam well.
Seven visits here equal one pilgrimage to Mecca.
trivia: The Great Mosque is the oldest in North Africa.
It was the capital of the Aghlabid dynasty.

clues: Best-preserved Spanish colonial city in Asia.
Known for its cobblestone streets and heritage houses.
fun_fact: The city planning follows the Spanish colonial blueprint.
Horse-drawn carriages are still a common transport.
trivia: It's a UNESCO World Heritage site.
The architecture blends Spanish and Asian designs.

clues: Medieval Hanseatic town on Gotland island.
Known for its well-preserved city wall.
fun_fact: The wall has 27 preserved towers and 3.4 km of original structure.
It was the only Hanseatic town with a wall this size.
trivia: The city hosts an annual Medieval Week.
It was a major Viking-age trading post.

clues: Ancient desert city with wind towers.
Known for its Zoroastrian heritage.
fun_fact: The wind towers are natural air conditioning systems.
Marco Polo visited the city in 1272.
trivia: It has the largest network of qanats (underground water channels).
The city has been continuously inhabited for 7,000 years.

clues: Lake city with 365 churches, one for each day.
Known for its ancient monasteries and beaches.
fun_fact: It was called the 'Jerusalem of the Balkans'.
The lake is over 3 million years old.
trivia: It's one of only 28 sites that are both cultural and natural UNESCO sites.
The city had the first Slavic university.

clues: Colonial river port frozen in time.
Known for its preserved colonial architecture.
fun_fact: The city inspired Gabriel García Márquez's works.
It was a major port for transporting gold during colonial times.
trivia: The city is built on an island in the Magdalena River.
It's famous for its unique style of filigree jewelry.

clues: Ancient Silk Road city with impressive minarets.
Known for its medieval Islamic architecture.
fun_fact: The city was once the capital of the Khwarezm Empire.
Genghis Khan destroyed the original city completely.
trivia: It was one of the largest cities in Central Asia.
The modern city was built near the ancient ruins.

clues: Colorful medieval citadel in Transylvania.
Birthplace of Vlad the Impaler (Dracula).
fun_fact: Nine of the original fourteen towers still stand.
The clock tower has different sized figures showing importance of citizens.
trivia: It's the last inhabited medieval citadel in Europe.
The city was founded by German craftsmen and merchants.

clues: Home to 11 rock-hewn churches.
Known as the 'New Jerusalem'.
fun_fact: The churches were carved from single pieces of rock.
They were built from the top down.
trivia: The construction took 23 years.
The churches are still active places of worship.

clues: Small island town with preserved medieval core.
Known for its Venetian architecture.
fun_fact: The town's layout hasn't changed since Hellenistic times.
The cathedral took four centuries to complete.
trivia: The Greeks founded the town in 3rd century BC.
It's called a 'Stone Beauty' due to its buildings.

clues: Ancient walled oasis city on the Silk Road.
Known for its intact inner fortress.
fun_fact: The inner city (Ichan Kala) is surrounded by brick walls.
It was the last rest stop for caravans before crossing the desert.
trivia: The city has over 50 historic monuments.
It was a major slave-trading center until the 20th century.

clues: Ancient capital of Yemen with unique architecture.
Known for its Great Mosque and university.
fun_fact: It was an important center of Islamic learning.
The city contributed to the development of algebra.
trivia: It has the highest concentration of mosques in Yemen.
The university was one of the oldest in the Islamic world.

clues: Medieval silver mining town with bone church.
Known for its Gothic cathedral and ossuary.
fun_fact: The Sedlec Ossuary contains bones from 40,000 people.
The city's wealth rivaled Prague's in medieval times.
trivia: It minted the Prague Groschen, central Europe's hard currency.
The bone church has a chandelier containing every bone in the human body.

clues: Ancient town perched on an eroding plateau.
Known as the 'Dying City' due to erosion.
fun_fact: The town is only accessible by a footbridge.
The population drops to about 12 people in winter.
trivia: The Etruscans founded it over 2,500 years ago.
The town sits atop a plateau of volcanic rock.
